refnamediv.refpurpose: unused. designed for the "Adopt-a-newbie" system, but never fully implemented.
unused. designed for the "Adopt-a-newbie" system, but never fully implemented.
Keeps track of what users are banning other users.

row.entry: The user userid of the banner.
The user userid of the bannee.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Lookup table for states, countries, languages, etc...

Provides a place to record that an action has been done, so it doesn't get done a second time later by a user accidentally double-clicking a single-click button in their browser.
The idea is that the application should grab a write lock for both the table it's inserting into, and the duplock table. Then, check the duplock table for a duplicate. If it's already in there, unlock the tables and remember the dupid to tell the user (app should pretend it was the first time... don't show an error message!), or if it's not in there, put it in the table, and then put the resulting uniqueid from the table handler into the duplock table (as dupid).
The duplock table is purged every hour or so of all locks older than an hour.

row.entry: The area of the site the lock is being provided for.
Realm ID. If you don't need it (most don't), use 0. Example: for comment realm, reid is the itemid being replied to.
The userid doing the action, or 0 if user is unknown (as in support realm)
The md5 digest of the event. Concatenate everything important and run it through perl's md5_hex (or MySQL's md5)
The unique ID this action generated the first time.
The time the action first completed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Categories that frequently asked questions can be classified under

Used for the processing of ibill.com receipts/transactions. Basically, it's a shared secret system... they give us a ton of codes and they give people buying payments those codes over time. When we run out, we need to ask for more and import them again.

row.entry: type of account: 100, 101, 102, 500, 501, 502. 1xx for credit card, 5xx for 900 number, 00 for $25, 01 for $15, 02 for $5/$5.95

refnamediv.refpurpose:
This table holds all journal entries, although the table name may be confusing (LiveJournal was originally called "Brad's log").
Actually, this table only stores metadata about journal entries... the actual content is stored in logtext.

row.entry: The user userid of the journal the entry is posted in.
The user userid of the person that posted the entry.
The time of the entry, according to the user's system clock.
The time of the entry, according to the server's clock.
The unique id given to the entry.
Either "N" or "Y", depending on whether the journal entry is compressed. Not supported yet. Always "N".
The security level of the post. "public" is for all, "private" is for only the poster, and "usemask" does a bitwase and of the allowmask and the groupmask of the friend viewing it.
A bitmask ... bit 0 is for all friends. bits 1-30 are used for friendgroups. bit 31 is reserved.
The number of people that have replied to this entry.
The year of the eventtime. Duplicated for an index.
The month of the eventtime. Duplicated for an index.
The day of the eventtime. Duplicated for an index.

refnamediv.refpurpose: List of possible meta-data for journal entries.
This table is a subset of the logtext table. This table is for selects when we know we only want the subject and we're selecting a lot of entries. The number of disk seeks is less.

row.entry: The journal entry's unique ID ... references log.
The subject of the journal entry.

refnamediv.refpurpose: This holds all the variable-length data for journal entries.

row.entry: The unique itemid of the journal entry. References the log table.
Journal entry subject. Also duplicated in the logsubject table.

refnamediv.refpurpose: List of different admin privileges that users can have.

Place to hold queries to do later in an efficient batch under an explicit table lock. Currently they're done every 10 seconds, but this will be changed to be dependent on the table they're being buffered for. The reason for this is because 2 writes/second is slow on often-read tables, but a batch of 20 or 30 every 10 seconds is very fast, if inside a LOCK TABLES ... UNLOCK TABLES

row.entry: Table to lock to do this query. Note: query CANNOT reference any other table, else it will fail. Need to make a querybuffer2 sometime that handles more complex locking
The time the query was buffered. Not used by applications, but useful for debugging/humans.
The query to be run later.

refnamediv.refpurpose: This table is the documentation for the database tables.

row.entry: The name of the table being described.
If set to 1, users can view the data in this table from the web. (lookup tables only)
Determines if data from this table is made available in the LJ source distribution. And if so, is it to be updated with upgrades (REPLACE INTO) or just inserted once.
A description of the table, for use in the schema browser, and in the LJ manual.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Categories for support system
Holds all fixed-length data about comments to journal entries. Indexes are all on this table. The actual text is in talktext, and the meta-data is in textprop.

row.entry: This field defines what type of thing in comment is in reply to. Values can be "L" = log item (journal entry), "T" = todo item.
For type "L", the log itemid. For type "T", the todo todoid.

refnamediv.refpurpose: List of possible meta-data for comments.
The types of color codes there can be. Part of the style system, version 1.

row.entry: A description of how that color code is used.
An integer specifying the order the color codes are to be displayed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Lists the system colors themes available to users.

row.entry: The #rrggbb color (or one of the constants)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Different color schemes. Hopefully this will die when the new style system replaces the current one.
We've had police and other authorities have us track some users with criminal activities going on. This table records those actions, when the user's tracking attribute is turned on in the user table.

row.entry: IP address they were coming from
If the police or a court has contact us to track a user, we turn this on and activities are logged to the tracking table.

refnamediv.refpurpose: List of possible meta-data on users.

row.entry: Unique id for this meta-data property.
Name of property, matching [a-z0-9_]+. Intended for use by code and clients.
Mixed case pretty name with spaces and punctuation. Indeded for use by humans.
Either "char" for text data, "num" for an integer, or "bool" for a 1/0 value.
Description of the meta-data, for use by developers (humans?)

refnamediv.refpurpose: ZIP Code table used to validate and auto-complete data that users enter about their location. More information can be found in the redudant table zips, which was imported later.

row.entry: State code (see codes for how to turn this into a full state name)

refnamediv.refpurpose: ZIP Code data for the United States that includes geographic coordinates. Only used with a ljmaint script that generates marker files for use in making xplanet maps. Most the LJ code uses the zip table instead.
